entry.title: Using Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP Applications (Db2 12.1 and Higher)
entry.content:
During numerous customer engagements, I learned that there is an increasing need, or even a mandate, to enable database auditing due to company policies, industry regulations, or the law. Auditing typically is enabled at both the SAP application level as well as the database level. Database-level auditing additionally captures workload and connections originating from outside the core SAP application, like direct connections to the database from a command line interface or the workload of third-party tools.
However, auditing both the SAP application and the database can lead to significant redundancy in audit data and thus can increase storage requirements.
This raises an important question: How can this redundancy be minimized or avoided, while still maintaining a secure and compliant audit trail?

 

Background

The basic concept of auditing in Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows has already been described in the blog post Using db2audit with SAP Applications. In addition, that blog post explains how to address the performance impact of auditing and how to reduce the amount of database-level audit data with Db2 11.5 and earlier.
However, the methods described still generate a considerable volume of audit data, so you may ask whether there is an additional measure for reducing the amount of database audit data collection.

Answer: Yes, there is.

Using the functionality of Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications can significantly reduce the amount of database audit data. Starting with Db2 12.1, the workload of the SAP NetWeaver Application Server ABAP primary connection for the SAP database connect user can be excluded from database audit. Consequently, the generation of redundant audit data can be significantly reduced, too. Technically, this is based on an audit exception for a trusted context, using a trust procedure. In addition, the Db2 database server processes an application token in combination with a NONCE to securely identify the SAP application.

Too complex? No, don’t worry.

At first glance, the concept consisting of a trusted connection, a trust procedure, and an audit exception sounds complex to set up, but fortunately it is not. You do not need to understand the implementation details of the trust procedure, application token, or NONCE, as all of this is already available and pre-defined in Db2 for SAP environments.
In this blog post, I describe the setup of filtered audit step-by-step. Additionally, I conducted a series of tests to explore how much the audit data volume gets reduced and whether there also exists a performance benefit with using Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications.

 

Prepare your system

To take advantage of the filtered audit functionality, your system must meet several prerequisites. The required features are available by default as of Db2 Version 12.1 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows.

  • If your environment is still running on Db2 11.5 or lower, an upgrade is required. For information about the upgrade process, see Upgrading to Version 12.1 of IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows on SAP Help Portal.
  • In addition, you need to update the SAP NetWeaver Application Server ABAP kernel as described in SAP Note 3422696 - DB6: enable trusted context for reduced application auditing.
  • Finally, there are new security screens in the DBA Cockpit that help you check and monitor Db2 audit. The blog post DBA Cockpit Enhancements for Db2 12.1 describes the new functionality. The new screens are delivered as part of the DBA Cockpit related code corrections for Db2 12.1 as described in SAP Note 3532234 - DB6: DBA Cockpit for IBM Db2 for LUW 12.1: Requirements and Enhancements . Make sure to implement those code corrections in your system.

 

 

Get Started

Once your system is prepared and running on Db2 12.1, you can begin configuring the filtered audit functionality. This process is outlined in the chapter “Db2 Audit and Audit Exceptions” of the Database Administration Guide for SAP on IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX, and Windows.

 The setup involves four key steps:

  1. Define a trusted context using a trust procedure.
  2. Establish a trusted connection.
  3. Define a database audit policy and activate it.
  4. Create an audit exception for the trusted context.

Trusted Context

The first step in configuring filtered audit is to define a trusted context.  Let’s first have a look at the new security screen in the DBA Cockpit (SAP transaction DBACOCKPIT). In the main menu, navigate to Configuration --> Security.

You should see entries already listed in the Trusted Context tab, which means the trusted context setup is already done. But how did this happen? Well, with Db2 V12.1 and higher, the trusted context setup typically happens automatically during the database installation post-processing or upgrade post-processing for SAP systems. Specifically, the db6_update_db script creates a trusted context for the SAP system database connect user (which is named “sapsr3” in my case).

Here’s an example of the SQL statement executed by the db6_update_db script:

CREATE TRUSTED CONTEXT DB6CTX_SAPSR3 BASED UPON CONNECTION USING SYSTEM AUTHID SAPSR3 ENABLE ATTRIBUTES (TRUST PROCEDURE SAPTOOLS.TRUST_PROC)

The above statement creates a trusted context named DB6CTX_SAPSR3, using a trust procedure called TRUST_PROC, which already exists in the SAPTOOLS schema. This procedure is specifically designed to work with SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP systems and allows for trusted connections to be established.

In the DBA Cockpit, you may also notice a second entry with the attribute “ENCRYPTION” set to “NONE”. This is automatically created with the trusted context and indicates that the context is valid for both encrypted and unencrypted connections. Check the CREATE TRUSTED CONTEXT statement in the IBM Db2 documentation for more details.

 

Trusted Connection

After having checked that the trusted context has already been set up automatically, let’s move to the Connections tab on the Security screen of the DBA Cockpit.

Most of the entries show disp+work processes of the SAP system, authenticated as SAP database connect user (which is “sapsr3” in the above example). The connections show “IMPLICIT” in the field “Trusted Context Type” and display the name of the already existing trusted context in the field “Trusted Context Name”. This indicates that the respective connections are trusted and are therefore subject to an audit exception.

You may also notice two entries in the list that do not display trusted context information.

  • One entry refers to an application named “db2bp”, indicating a database connection from a Db2 command line interface. These types of connections are intended to be audited and therefore are not implicitly trusted.
  • The second non-trusted entry represents a disp+work process. But in contrast to the other disp+work connections, it is authorized as the Db2 instance owner and represents a database connection initiated by the DBA Cockpit. Since the DBA Cockpit allows administrative database operations, auditing these connections is intended and they are therefore not implicitly trusted.   

 

Key takeaway

With the trusted context enabled, only the primary SAP application connections, established by the SAP connect user via a disp+work process, will be excluded from auditing. 
Consequently, Db2 will continue to audit the following:

  • Any other authorization ID that connects to the database
  • SAP executables like R3trans, R3load, db6util, tp, etc.
  • External tools like replication tools, monitoring tools, reporting tools, scheduling tools, etc.

 

Define and activate an audit policy

The most challenging step in the setup is probably the creation of an audit policy. While the technical setup is straightforward, the real challenge lies in defining the scope of what should be audited. Audit requirements are typically shaped by a combination of legislation, industry regulation, and company policies.  As a result, the audit policy must be tailored to each organization’s unique compliance landscape, and therefore I cannot provide a one-size-fits-all policy in this blog post.

And the good news is…

Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications reduces the amount of database audit data significantly. This makes it easier to define the scope of the database-level audit because it is now possible to implement a quite comprehensive audit policy while at the same time having a manageable audit trail and a significantly reduced volume of audit data.  In the examples shown in this blog post, I used such a comprehensive audit policy.

 

Process

To enable database auditing, you need to take the following steps:

  1. Define and create an audit policy.
  2. Configure target paths to store audit data and archived audit data.
  3. Configure the Db2 audit buffer.
  4. Activate the audit policy for your database.

The following example statement uses all available database audit categories to create a comprehensive audit policy. 

db2 "create audit policy comprehensivepolicy categories 
     audit status both, checking status both, 
     objmaint status both, secmaint status both, 
     sysadmin status both, validate status both, 
     execute status both, 
     context status both error type audit"

Next, configure two storage locations for the audit data files: one for active audit logs and another one for archived audit logs. Use the following commands to set these paths:

db2audit configure datapath /db2audit/auditlogs
db2audit configure archivepath /db2audit/auditarchive

Now configure the audit buffers. There exist two audit buffers and you can define their size using the database manager parameter “AUDIT_BUF_SZ”, in a unit of 4k pages. 
The default setting of the AUDIT_BUF_SZ parameter is “0”. This means that no buffers are used and that audit data will be written to disk synchronously. You may experience a significant performance impact when using this setting.
Make sure to set the AUDIT_BUF_SZ parameter to a value greater than “0”. In this case, two equally sized buffers will be allocated from the database heap. The setting of the parameter defines the size of each audit buffer. Using a round-robin approach, audit data is first written to one of the buffers. As soon as this first buffer gets full, or at certain time intervals, the content from the first buffer is flushed into an audit file on disk. At the same time, the database continues to write its audit data into the second audit buffer.
Tip: Check SAP Note 1474404 - DB6: Poor database performance with DB2AUDIT for a recommended setting of the audit buffer size. The value of 4096 4k-pages is a good starter.
Use the following command to set both audit buffers to a size of 4096 4k-pages each:

db2 "update DBM CFG using AUDIT_BUF_SZ 4096"

Finally, activate the policy as follows, using the name of the policy you defined when creating it:

db2 "audit database using policy comprehensivepolicy"

If necessary, you can deactivate the policy again by removing it, using the following command. This effectively will stop database-level auditing.

db2 "audit database remove policy"

On the Security screen of the DBA Cockpit, on the Db2 Audit tab, you can review your setup.

At the top of the screen, you can see the settings for the configured audit buffer size as well as the audit data and audit archive paths.
Note: Instance Audit active should be set to “No” as we configured database-level auditing only and no instance-level auditing.
The database-level audit policy settings are shown in the table on the screen. The second column Audit Status shows whether the configured policy is active or not, and the subsequent columns show the configuration of the individual audit categories.

 

Create an audit exception

In the last step of setting up Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications, you define an audit exception for the trusted context. With this, all activities of trusted connections are exempted from the database audit trail.
Use the following command to set up the audit exception for the trusted context:

db2 "audit add exception for trusted context DB6CTX_SAPSR3"

Next, switch back to the Trusted Context tab on the Security screen of the DBA Cockpit.

You now see the entry Audit Exception in the column Exception Type.
This means that you have successfully enabled Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications.

 

Testing Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP Applications

How effective is the filtered audit functionality?

To answer this question, I conducted a series of tests and measured both the volume of audit data as well as the performance impact. For all tests, Db2 database-level auditing was active using the same set of audit categories, that is, I used the comprehensive audit policy as described in this blog post. I executed the tests both with an active audit exception as well as without an audit exception, this means with and without using the Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications. The tests were performed on an SAP NetWeaver 7.50 AS ABAP system running on Db2 12.1 on Linux.

Test scenarios

I set up the following three test scenarios:

  1. Generating workload using the SAP HA Test Tool. This tool initially was created to test high-availability scenarios under workload. However, also for non-HA setups, it is perfectly suited for workload generation with a configurable load and runtime. In a nutshell, the tool processes order items, performing INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements on a handful of tables. The tool measures dialog steps per second as well as the response time.
  2. Re-generation of SAP ABAP programs with transaction SGEN and component SAP_ABA.
  3. Stopping and starting the SAP Application Servers, including the Db2 instance.

Before and after each test, I archived the Db2 audit log file to measure the amount of audit data generated during each test.
You can archive the active audit log using the following command:

db2audit archive database <DBSID>

 

Results

The following tables show the results of my tests using the comprehensive audit policy and an audit buffer of 4096 4k-pages.

Looking at the results, the performance metrics are all in the same order of magnitude, with a slight but consistent advantage for the audit exception scenarios, which is expected with a properly tuned audit buffer.
The true benefit of Db2 Filtered Audit, however, is clearly visible when looking at the audit file sizes that represent the amount of audit data being generated during the tests.  The decrease of audit data varies between factor 8 for the "Stopping  and Starting SAP” test case, by factor 261 for the SAP HA test tool case, and by factor 2345 for the SGEN test case.

In a nutshell

Using Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications shows some performance benefits and reduces the amount of database audit data . Not only does a reduced volume of audit data save a significant amount of disk space, but it also eases the subsequent analysis of the audit data trail.

2nd test cycle

In a second test cycle, I evaluated the effect of the audit buffers on system performance. For this, I executed the SAP HA test tool multiple times, modifying the values of the database manager configuration parameter “AUDIT_BUF_SZ“ for each run.  I used audit buffer values of 0 (which results in a synchronous write to the audit file), 100, 1000, 4096, 10000 and 20000 pages.

First, let’s look at the results without using the audit exception for the trusted context.

With an audit buffer set to a value of 0, the measured number of dialog steps per second ended at 1,1 and the average response time at 78 seconds. You could call this being close to a virtual system standstill. Note the logarithmic scale on the response time axis in the chart. Even with a small audit buffer of 100 pages, the performance improved significantly and incrementally increased further with bigger audit buffer sizes.  The moderate value of 4096 pages of audit buffer, as recommended in SAP Note 1474404 - DB6: Poor database performance with DB2AUDIT, proved to be a good setting for this test case.

Next, let’s look at the results with using an audit exception for the trusted context.

With Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications in place, the performance penalty for synchronous writes of audit files was not as significant. Again, the SAP-recommended audit buffer size setting of 4096 pages proved to work very well.

 

Summary

Here are your key takeaways on using Db2 Filtered Audit for SAP applications:

  • It is straight-forward to set up, and monitoring is integrated in the DBA Cockpit.
  • It reduces the amount of database audit data significantly and mainly avoids data redundancy with SAP application-based auditing. A reduced amount of audit data also eases the subsequent analysis of the audit data trail.
  • It eases the definition of audit policies as it allows for more comprehensive policy setups while keeping the amount of generated audit data at a manageable level.
  • It still audits non-SAP workload as well as external SAP tools.
  • Having a properly sized audit buffer for good system performance is less important when using filtered audit. The SAP recommendation of 4096 4k pages is still a good starter.

entry.title: Security, Data Protection and IAM guidelines in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Security is a fundamental component throughout the entire lifecycle of SAP products, including development, planning, and quality assurance. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP manages infrastructure-level security such as network protection, operating system security, and patch management. Security responsibilities requiring business-specific decisions—such as user and authorization management—are handled by the customer. In certain cases, SAP provides secure default configurations, which customers can adjust to suit specific business or integration requirements. Overall, SAP covers key security domains at the platform level, while customers are responsible for application-level security and configuration.

We have now added new Security and Data Protection Guidelines within the SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) Roadmap.

As an introduction to SAP Activate Methodology, The SAP Activate Roadmaps is a comprehensive, phase-based guide designed to support implementation, conversion, and upgrade projects by defining tasks, deliverables, responsibilities, and accelerators across six key phases: Discover, Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy, and Run. It provides methodology guidance, clear role and task allocation, and a rich set of accelerators such as templates and checklists to streamline activities like system provisioning, data migration, and cutover planning. Regularly updated to align with SAP’s quarterly cloud releases, the roadmap also offers specialized paths for system conversions and upgrades, and integrates with SAP Cloud ALM to enable real-time task management, progress tracking, and agile project execution, ensuring efficient and best-practice-driven project delivery.

Here is an overview of the topics and guidelines covered in each of the phases from a Security & Data Protection perspective

Prepare:

  • Review the recommendations that help you evaluate the security of the configuration of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in your landscape. As part of the cloud shared responsibility model(restricted access), you're responsible for determining if any of these recommendations are relevant to your environment and to what extent.
  • Integrate security recommendations into the overall implementation strategy, ensuring that the security plan comprehensively covers the following areas:
    • Implementation Aspects – including evaluation of integration security posture, frontend protection planning, and authentication design;
    • Recurring Topics – such as certificate management planning, security monitoring setup, user lifecycle management design, and planning for the security and patching of external software.

These topics are critical to establishing a secure, compliant, and well-governed SAP S/4HANA Cloud environment.

Explore:

  • Conduct Data Protection Workshop

Define and confirm the implementation scope and configuration settings related to data protection and privacy, ensuring compliance with both general and industry-specific legal requirements. The workshop focuses on understanding SAP’s data protection concepts, identifying relevant project areas such as application design, extensibility, integration, testing, data management, and analytics, and determining where data protection measures must be applied. Key outcomes include clarifying responsibilities, reviewing system configurations, defining data retention policies, and ensuring transparency over personal data processing. The result is a comprehensive plan that outlines required actions for data protection experts and stakeholders to ensure secure and compliant system operations.

  • Plan and Design Identity and Access Management

Plan and design the Identity and Access Management (IAM) framework for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ensuring proper authorization and secure access to applications. This involves consolidating business requirements captured during fit-to-standard workshops, defining a clear authorization concept with naming conventions, specifying required workplaces, and mapping SAP applications and business catalogs to these workplaces. All technical IAM details must be collected, documented, and approved by the customer. The authorization concept should ensure data integrity, protection against misuse, and be transparent enough for third-party verification. The finalized IAM framework also supports test planning and execution.

Realize:

  • Initial access to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Tenants

Setup Integration to Corporate IdP if needed by setting up the SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service as a proxy. Configure password policies and multi-factor authentication (MFA) in your IdP (Identity Authentication service or corporate IdP)

  • Configure data protection and privacy features based on the design defined during the Fit-to-Standard workshop. Key steps include defining data controllers, setting retention and residence policies for transactional and master data, managing security audit log retention, and maintaining purposes for information retrieval. Additionally, configure read access logging and consent administration if applicable.
  • Implement Frontend Security settings focusing on web client protection measures
  • Review and adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or an upgrade
  • Configure Identity and Access Management

This task involves creating, configuring, and testing custom business roles based on approved identity and access management requirements. It includes assigning business catalogs and restriction field values according to the Application-Workplace List, creating test users, and ensuring roles cover all necessary access through completeness and negative testing. Authorization testing is coordinated across business areas, with roles refined and validated based on feedback.

Deploy:

  • Finalize and validate all security configurations and data protection measures before the system goes live

Run:

  • Security Operations

Maintain system security, compliance, and audit readiness through continuous activities defined in the Prepare phase. Key ongoing operations include regular log monitoring (covering business data changes, user and role changes, and security audits), periodic reviews of Identity and Access Management for business and communication users, and proactive certificate management to prevent expirations and manage trust lists. Additionally, configuration monitoring is performed to ensure system integrity, collectively supporting a secure and compliant SAP environment.

Use the tag Security-Data Protection-IAM to access Security, Data Protection and IAM content in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) Roadmap

You can explore more SAP Activate resources in SAP Community using tag  #sapactivate, we also encourage you to consider following our sister communities SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Cloud ALM. Let us know your thoughts in the comments to this blog post or via questions in the SAP Activate community.

entry.title: How to get 10000 developers to securely deliver their software
entry.content:
Let’s start with a few numbers: SAP S/4HANA contains more than 300 million lines of code, the software runs more than 90% of the world’s largest corporations and, most importantly for the scope of this article, it currently keeps about 10.000 developers at SAP busy. Those developers are spread all over the globe, covering pretty much every time zone. In this challenging setup, how do you ensure the secure delivery of software? Short answer: transparency. Long answer: continue reading.

Obviously, the answer is more complex than that. In order to ensure the security of a software that complex with that many developers in a decentralized setup, quite a few measures have to be in place in order to ensure securely written code and applications. These issues are addressed by SAP, as we have implemented a „shift-Left“ approach to security early on, including a product standard for security, a secure development and operations lifecycle (we need to secure our cloud environments, too), and, of course various tools and trainings to support developers in developing secure code in the first place.

Nevertheless, with 10.000 people working on the code daily, overseeing the security posture of the written code can be challenging, to say the least. This is why we have come up with the „Security Execution Dashboard“. At this point, we have to make a confession: there’s not much new stuff in the dashboard – but as with a lot of good things, it’s the combination of existing features and functions that make the dashboard so powerful – and is one of the reasons it won the prestigious CSO50 award this year, making it the second year in a row that SAP was able to win this particular award. Let’s deep dive into what made the security execution dashboard award-winning.

One of the biggest technical hurdles was the sheer diversity of tools involved. SAP’s security landscape includes a mix of industry-standard scanners like GitHub, Blackduck, and Checkmarx, as well as SAP’s own tools like FioriDAST. Each of these tools speaks its own language—different data formats, different APIs, different update cycles. To make sense of this chaos, the team built a unified data extraction framework. Think of it as a translator that sits between the dashboard and each tool, standardizing the way data is pulled, parsed, and processed. Every tool got its own connector or adapter, ensuring that no matter how the data looked coming in, it would be clean and consistent going out.

But pulling the data was only half the battle. The next challenge was making it meaningful. Security data is only useful if it’s tied to the right team, the right product, and the right release. That meant building a harmonized data model that could map scan results to specific areas of responsibility. This wasn’t just a matter of matching names—it required defining mapping rules, building validation mechanisms, and ensuring that the same issue wasn’t counted twice or missed entirely. The result is a dashboard that doesn’t just show you what’s wrong—it shows you who needs to fix it.

Performance was another sticking point. Querying live data from all these tools in real time would have brought the system to its knees. So the team implemented caching and temporary in-memory storage to keep things fast and responsive. Frequently accessed data is now stored locally, reducing the load on source systems and ensuring that developers aren’t left waiting for their dashboards to load.

Data quality also proved to be a recurring issue. In the early days, scan results were often misattributed or incomplete, making it hard to trust the insights. To fix this, the team introduced a robust data quality management process. Automated validation checks, regular audits, and feedback loops with tool owners helped tighten the accuracy of the data and improve the reliability of team mappings.

And then there was the human side. Convincing thousands of developers to adopt a new tool—especially one that shines a light on security gaps—is no small feat. The team tackled this with a mix of early engagement, pilot programs, and a strong internal communications push. Over time, the dashboard earned its place as the go-to source for security insights, not by mandate, but by proving its value.

Today, the Security Execution Dashboard is more than just a reporting tool. It’s a living system that adapts to the needs of SAP’s engineering teams. It’s fast, it’s accurate, and it’s deeply integrated into the way SAP builds software. And most importantly, it’s helped shift the conversation around security—from something that happens after the fact, to something that’s embedded from the very first line of code.

entry.title: High-Availability Setup for SAP Secure Login Service with Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI is SAP’s solution for secure authentication and single sign-on in SAP GUI scenarios. The service is based on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) and supports the platform capabilities for high availability (HA).

In most cases this will be sufficient for customers, in particular as SAP Secure Login Service is only required during an end-user’s initial authentication of the day. When this is successful, an X.509 certificate is deployed on the end-user desktop, which gives her single sign-on, usually for the rest of the working day.

Still, some customers would like to go beyond the standard HA capabilities and instead implement a dedicated, multi-region failover setup.

In this blog, I will describe the steps that are necessary to configure this setup. It is based on SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI, SAP Custom Domain service and Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Many thanks to Microsoft’s @MartinRaepple for helping me get started with Traffic Manager. This blog is yet another outcome of our great collaboration over the years 🙂

 

Setting up SAP Secure Login Service for multi-region failover

 

  1. Subscribe to SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI from two SAP BTP subaccounts in different regions, in the same global account. Let us assume that the two instances of SAP Secure Login Service have the URLs sls-customer.region1.cloud.sap and sls-customer.region2.cloud.sap.
  2. In each region, configure the same custom domain and map it to the local SAP Secure Login Service standard route. Let us assume that the custom domain has the URL sls.customer.com. For the custom domain to work, you also need to add the OpenID Connect redirect URIs in SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication.
  3. Introduce a traffic management solution. In this example, we use Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Let us assume that the Traffic Manager profile has the URL sls.trafficmanager.net. Add the URLs of the two SAP Secure Login Service instances as endpoints to the Traffic Manager profile.
  4. Configure the routing method, based on which Traffic Manager will switch end points. For testing, you might use the priority of the end points, which means that the switch takes place if you change the priority in the Traffic Manager configuration. In a productive scenario, you would choose technical indicators of availability, such as performance.
  5. Traffic Manager will automatically configure the DNS record of sls.trafficmanager.net to point to the optimal endpoint, based on the routing method. Let us assume that in the beginning this is region 1.
  6. Configure the DNS record of your custom domain sls.customer.com so that it points to the Traffic Manager URL sls.trafficmanager.net.
  7. Enter the custom domain sls.customer.com as the SAP Secure Login Service host name in Secure Login Client on the end-user desktop.
     

 

Handling of the failover case

 

  1. Let us assume that due to some technical reason, SAP Secure Login Service in region 1 becomes unresponsive.
  2. Traffic Manager checks all endpoints at regular intervals (e.g., every 10 seconds) and detects the issue.
  3. Traffic Manager updates the DNS record for sls.trafficmanager.net to point to sls-customer.region2.cloud.sap.
  4. The next time Secure Login Client connects to SAP Secure Login Service, the DNS name sls.customer.com is automatically resolved to point to the service instance in region 2.

 

Further considerations

This blog covers the high-availability setup of SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI. As SAP Secure Login Service relies on an identity provider for end-user authentication, this also needs to be available at runtime. SAP’s identity provider, SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication, also offers a multi-region setup. If you use a 3rd party identity provider, check the documentation of that product to learn more about options for high availability.

SAP Secure Login Service issues end-user certificates that enable authentication for SAP NetWeaver ABAP-based systems such as SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA. During authentication, the X.509 certificate is mapped to a user account in the ABAP system, if the SNC name of that user account matches the subject name of the certificate. In the default implementation of SAP Secure Login Service, information about the region becomes part of the subject name. As a result, switching to a different region breaks the mapping.

There are two options to ensure that the SNC mapping remains intact:

  • Use parameters of the SAP Cryptographic Library to strip the region names from the certificate subject before the mapping takes place. That way, certificates from different regions will match the same SNC name. See note 2338952 for details.
  • Change the SAP Secure Login Service configuration to use a customer-managed certificate authority. This gives you the option to customize the subject name of the certificate so that it does not include the BTP region.

 

Conclusion

Setting up SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI for multi-region failover is easy. All you need is SAP Custom Domain service and a traffic management solution such as Microsoft Azure Traffic Manager. Thanks to the flexibility of the configuration, end-users continue to benefit from single sign-on even if SAP Secure Login Service instances are switched in the background.

 

More information

For more information about our SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI solution and to stay up to date on the latest developments, visit our topic page in SAP Community. Also, take a look at @MartinRaepple's blog SAP GUI MFA with Microsoft Entra: Integration with SAP Secure Login Service.

entry.title: Deploy built-in SAP LogServ detection rules in Microsoft Sentinel and extend to your needs - Part 3
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following the product release blog by SAP regarding the integration of SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, I am going to share some details on the built-in detection rules and how you can build upon them.

The most discussed log in my customer conversations so far was SAP HANA database. So, let’s start with that.

 

Discover the available built-in detections from the Content Hub

Find the relevant section both from the Azure or the unified Defender portal under Rule templates in the Analytics section. They are available from version 3.0.2 of the SAP LogServ solution.

 

Typical database threat scenarios involve tampering with audit log settings, admin authorizations or privileged role assignments.

We have taken the existing battle-proven Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP rules for HANA DB and translated them to be compatible with the LogServ schema. The raw log source is Syslog in both cases. So, the only remaining step was “unboxing” of the JSON wrapper.

To understand the individual columns of the LogServ output, see SAP’s HANA Audit Trail Layout for Trail Target documentation. For ease of use we have numbered the columns and applied the same names SAP mentions on their docs.

 

Activate the new rules

Navigate to the Analytics pane and select the rule you want, click “Create Rule” from the button with the three dots and follow the configuration wizard. See the severity classification and pre-defined MITRE attack framework mapping. These mappings help streamline your SOC analysts’ triage efforts.

 

 

Verify the rule execution schedule and consider automated responses where feasible. Creating ServiceNow tickets for instance is a popular action. See my dedicated blog series on SOAR for SAP for inspiration.

From the “Review + Create” section click save. Your rule is now live!

 

Build upon or extend the provided analytic rules

Since the Kusto Query is fully transparent to you (see above screenshot) it is easy to derive your own tailored scenarios from it.

For instance, take analytic rule “Deactivation of Audit Trail” and extend the client IP address attribute (client_ip_address__col_7) to project in plain English if that is an internal or external IP.

| extend GeoLocation= iff(ipv4_is_private(client_ip_address__col_7),
dynamic({"IsPrivate": true}),
geo_info_from_ip_address(client_ip_address__col_7))

I have a feeling this might be of interest during your incident triage process 😉

 

Final Words

That’s a wrap🌯. You saw today how to discover the built-in analytic rules of the SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel and how easy it is to extend them for your own individual needs. The rule catalog gets extended continuously based on customer demand.

Your existing investments in SAP infrastructure detections in Sentinel can easily be made compatible with the LogServ schema, because SAP simply forwards the logs unaltered as raw messages. The only required step is the unboxing of their JSON root message.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Which detections or analytic rules for RISE do you need most? Let me know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: First smoke test after SAP LogServ solution deployment in Microsoft Sentinel - Part 0
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Due to the asynchronous integration between SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, it's advisable to perform a smoke test yourself before sharing your config data with SAP. This helps confirm if your receiving connector setup works and ensures the correct configuration will be shared with SAP the first time round.

 

Run a smoke test for ease of mind

Once the SAP LogServ push-connector is deployed on Microsoft Sentinel, you can start posting data towards its data collection endpoint. Use the provided REST client collection, or scripts to replicate the exact requests details that LogServ is performing too.

Maintain the variables as per your environment, see the LogServ sample payload and start posting. A working request shows http code 204 with no content on the response. See a sample output from the provided powershell script for reference. I prefer REST clients but people are different 😎

 

Find the parameters from the SAP LogServ Sentinel connector wizard on initial connect (see screenshot below). You can also get them directly from the individual resources. The data collection endpoint and data collection rule are created in the same resource group as your Log Analytics workspace underpinning Sentinel. They are prefixed with “SAPLogServ”. The app registration on Entra ID can be found from the Entra Application ID field.

 

Use the 2 KQL queries below to inspect your first data entry on the SAPLogServ_CL table in Sentinel.

SAPLogServ_CL
| take 10
SAPLogServ_CL
| summarize count() by clz_dir, clz_subdir
| order by clz_dir asc, clz_subdir asc

 

Wait a minute or two on first try. The population of new tables takes a short time initially.

Alternatively, deploy the SAP LogServ insights workbook on Sentinel for visual oversight. 

 

Once saved to your workspace, start looking for the smoke test result. It covers all your observabilty needs going forward.

 

Hurray you have a functioning data collection endpoint for the SAP LogServ data🎉

Now, continue your onboarding journey by sharing the config data with SAP over your chosen channel. Find the details on SAP's blog here.

What if you don’t see the data entry on the LogServ table?

  1. Verify the connection details: Did you really hit the right endpoint? Are you looking in the right tenant and log analytics workspace?
  2. Verify selection criteria: Is your Time range filter accurate? The smoke tests create entries for NOW or 30mins earlier in UTC.
  3. Did enough time pass on the initial table population? Consider a retry of the KQL query.
  4. Verify the Data collection rule has not been changed to filter all results or similar. See this blog part and KQL snippet for more details.

 

Deployment fully messed up?

The simplest way to a fresh start is a delete and redeployment of the Log Analytics workspace. In case that is not an option you need to delete the LogServ connector resources to reset the LogServ solution in Sentinel. The data collection endpoint, data collection rule and entra id app registration can be deleted from the Azure portal. But the data connector itself needs to be deleted via API.

For your convenience, use this REST API request collection to drop the resources. Once performed the LogServ connector UI will activate the deploy button again. In case you went fully bazooka and also deleted the SAPLogServ_CL table from your Log Analytics worksapce that needs to be reverted too. If the table had data you need to run a restore operation from Azure CLI.

 

Final Words

That’s a wrap🌯. You saw today how to streamline your onboarding experience of SAP LogServ in Microsoft Sentinel. Simple smoke tests ensure a speedy onboarding and confidence in the shared setup configuration.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: Q2 2025: Quarterly Release Highlights: SAP BTP Security and Identity & Access Management
entry.content:
In the second quarter of 2025, we released several new features and enhancements. Did you know that you can find all new feature announcements for SAP Cloud Identity Services in the SAP Cloud Identity Services Release Notes on the SAP Help Portal?

Let’s take a look at some of our recent highlights!

Identity Provisioning Service: Job log improvements

The Job Execution Outcome is now displayed on the Job Execution Details screen and included in the job notifications. It appears when delta-read jobs and jobs that fail to read entities from the source system affect the deletion of entities in the target system.
For more information, see Monitor Provisioning Job Logs.

You can now download and view the details of all deleted entities by a provisioning job. To enable this, set the property ips.trace.deleted.entity to true.
For more information, see Manage Provisioning Job Logs and List of Properties.

Identity Directory Service and Identity Provisioning Service: Support for extension schemas towards many SAP business applications

We now support a number of extension schemas, including

  • SAP extension schema for groups
  • Extension enterprise schema for users
  • SAP ODM User Schema Support

You can find details in the SAP Cloud Identity Release Notes.

Extension of the Identity Directory’s SCIM API

The Identity Directory API of SAP Cloud Identity Services now returns the termsOfUse and privacyPolicy parameters. For more information, check Identity Directory API.

In addition, we now support application-specific group assignments. You can find details in the SAP Help Portal chapters on Identity Authentication and the Local Identity Directory.

Management of Corporate Identity Providers via API

Tenant administrators can manage corporate identity providers in Identity Authentication via API. It offers endpoints for CRUD operations (GET, POST, PATCH, DELETE) over the corporate identity providers. See SAP Cloud Identity Services Corporate Identity Providers Directory.

Configuration of Password Expiration Reminder

You can configure the system to show a password expiration reminder on the user’s sign-in page. For more information, check Enable Password Expiration Reminder.

Enabling SAP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI with support for Microsoft Windows mandatory profiles

We added support for single sign-on on shopfloor Windows-based computers that are configured to use a mandatory profile. This protects shopfloor computers with a restrictive mandatory profile while still offering single sign-on support for desktop clients of SAP GUI. You can find more information in the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Cloud Foundry Login Based on JSON Web Tokens (JWTs)

When building CI/CD pipelines, developers are responsible for managing the credentials used by these pipelines for authentication to external systems. This traditionally requires developers to take care of the lifecycle of the credentials, including secure storage and regular rotation of the credentials, which comes with repeated efforts and might be error-prone.

In his latest blog post, Authenticating GitHub Actions Workflows Deploying to the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry Environment with JWTs, Sebastian Ries explains how to authenticate to the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment from a GitHub Actions workflow using GitHub-issued short-lived JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), eliminating the need for manual secret management and enabling secure, efficient CI/CD workflows. 

Want to stay up to date on our services? Join our SAP BTP Security, Single Sign-On for SAP GUI and SAP Cloud Identity Services communities!

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
entry.content:
The APIs for process automation are quite important to building integration scenarios with processes. But many people do not know how to get started, and even experienced users do not know how to work with environments or how to handle authentication or when an API key is needed.

So here is a guide to the APIs.

NOTE: I assume that you already know how to work with process automation, and you know the ins and outs of creating and triggering process projects using the SAP Build UI.

 

What can you do with APIs

If you just use forms to trigger a process, and then the process runs with actions and approval forms, you may not need to use the APIs. But most sophisticated processes will require you to make use of the APIs. So here is a list of some of things you can do with the APIs:

  • Trigger a process (sending in input values)
  • Get the status of a process instance
  • Get the context and execution log of a process instance
  • Change the status of a process instance (such as suspend or cancel)
  • Get a list of existing processes
  • Get a list of open user tasks
  • Approve or reject an approval form
  • Execute any form, and select which button of the form to simulate pressing
  • Call a decision (business rule) to get the appropriate output
  • Get a list of automation jobs that were run
  • ... and much more

 

Where to get information on APIs

The best place to go to get basic reference information about the APIs is, of course, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Search for Process Automation, and then under APIs you will see the package of APIs.

Click the SAP Build Process Automation package, and you will see 1 OData API and 6 REST API. The key APIs are the REST APIs. 

Here's a link to get to the SAP Build Process Automation package directly.

 

Authentication and Permissions

The most complex part of working with the APIs is the authentication, and understanding the types of authentication and what each enables you to do.

2 Main Authentication Methods

There are 2 main ways to perform OAuth2 authentication:

  • Client Credentials, where you are signing in as the service, which has essentially admin rights (but not complete access to all information)
  • User Token, where you are signing in as a user (you) with whatever rights you have been given, both in terms of process automation roles and permissions in a specific SAP Build environment (more on environments later)

Why is this important?

Because you often want to know who the user is who is calling the API. For example, when triggering a process, the user who makes the API call is the one listed in the Monitoring tab. If that's not important, you can use client credentials with a service key.

Or, if you are retrieving workflow instances from an environment, only a member from that environment with the correct permissions can access the workflow instances. Using client credentials with the client id/secret will not work.

Client Credentials

To connect, with Client Credentials, you send a Client ID and Client Secret, derived from the service key.

In the cockpit, where you created an instance of the SAP Build Process Automation service, you need to create a service key. 

You only need supply a name for the key.

Once you create the key, you can view the key's detail by clicking View.

This displays something like this:

You only need the following fields to log in:

  • api: The host of the APIs
  • clientid: Username
  • clientsecret: Password
  • url: Authentication URL to get the authorization token (the URL is this URL with /oauth/token appended)

So if you were setting up a destination, this is how it would work:

User Token

But many times, perhaps most times, you do not want to use a service user but you want to know who is making the call. This is important, for example, if the call is to approve the task, so only the user to whom the task is assigned should be updating the task. Or, as we mentioned above, only a real member of an environment can retrieve workflow instances from a shared environment.

With a destination, the only change you need to make is to change the Authentication field to OAuth2JWTBearer, and this will make sure to retrieve and send a token for the current user. All other destination fields are the same.

Environments

With the relatively new shared environments (i.e., all environments except Public), you sometimes need to indicate in the API call to which environment you are making the call to. For example, a process may be deployed to multiple environments, so when you call to trigger it, you need to specify in which environment to trigger it.

To do this, you add this query parameter:

?environmentId=MyEnvironment

Similarly, if you want to retrieve all the process instances from a particular environment, your API URL might look like this:

https://spa-api-gateway-bpi-us-prod.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances?environmentId=danielshared

 

Try Out on Accelerator Hub

Let's try to access our SAP Build Process Automation process instances from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Go to the GET workflow-instances API. On the left menu, click Workflow Instances, and then select the first API call.

Click Add New Environment on the right, and fill in the details using the values from your service key.

Call the environment My Trial BTP, select the authentication domain for your tenant (for my trial account it was http://authentication.us10.hana.ondemand.com/) and then when entering the consumer subdomain, only enter the subdomain for your subaccount. 

At the bottom indicate you want to save the environment for the future, and click Configure. It might take a minute for the configuration to save.

Then, on the right, select the environment, and click Run. You should get your workflow instances.

entry.title: Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
entry.content:
By Helen Oakley, Senior Director of Software and AI Security, SAP Global Security & Cloud Compliance 

This year, at SAP Sapphire, SAP unveiled its expanded vision for Business AI, introducing a growing network of Joule Agents that work across systems and lines of business. This marks a clear step into the era of Agentic AI – systems that can understand context, take initiative, and drive outcomes autonomously. “SAP combines the world’s most powerful suite of business applications with uniquely rich data and the latest AI innovations to create a flywheel of customer value,” said CEO Christian Klein. While this evolution opens exciting possibilities for automation and productivity, it also introduces a new layer of complexity in how we approach security. Agentic systems challenge traditional safeguards, making it essential to identify and mitigate risks early through tailored threat modeling. 

At its core, threat modeling is about asking the right questions early in the development process, while the system is still being designed and built. Rather than simply looking for bugs or code flaws, it forces us to think through how a system might behave in the real world. What could go wrong if an agent’s goals are manipulated? Could someone poison its memory over time? What if an agent uses a tool in an unintended or unsafe way? How could agent-generated content be used to mislead or overload human decision-makers? What happens when agents collaborate or collide in ways that expose the system to cascading failures or manipulation? 

These are not hypothetical questions. They reflect the real and emerging risks of agentic systems. The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide is a valuable resource that brings structure to this thinking. It highlights specific threats such as memory poisoning, cascading hallucinations, privilege compromise, and agent communication poisoning. For teams building these systems, it helps provide a common vocabulary and practical examples to guide threat modeling work. 

To give an example of how threat modeling helps in practice, let’s take the case of goal manipulation – one of the emerging risks identified in the OWASP guide. In agentic systems, attackers don’t necessarily need to exploit traditional software flaws. Instead, they can attempt to influence an agent’s behavior over time by subtly manipulating its objectives. This might happen through indirect prompt injection, compromised data sources, or crafted tool responses. Imagine an agent responsible for prioritizing financial transactions; if adversarial inputs gradually shift its decision logic, it could start approving risky payments outside of the intended policy. In threat modeling exercises, we explore how such scenarios could play out by analyzing how the agent forms and updates its goals, how memory and feedback loops could reinforce undesired behaviors, and how downstream actions might be impacted. This helps define targeted mitigations, such as isolating goal-setting logic from external inputs, monitoring shifts in agent behavior, and adding human validation for sensitive decisions. 

The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide provides a helpful reference architecture that illustrates where these types of risks can emerge. The diagram below maps threats to key components in a typical agentic system, making it easier to visualize how threat modeling applies in practice. 

Image Source: OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations guide, “Threat Model Summary” 

At SAP, threat modeling has long been part of our Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (Secure SDOL), which is certified under ISO 27001. This framework ensures security is built into every phase of the product lifecycle, from design to operations. With Agentic AI, we are expanding our threat modeling approach to address risks that don’t typically appear in traditional application security. This includes analyzing agent memory behavior, reasoning patterns, system autonomy, human interaction points, and the dynamics of multi-agent ecosystems. The focus shifts from identifying static vulnerabilities to understanding how autonomy and learning can lead to unintended behaviors. From there, we define appropriate controls and mitigations to reduce those risks. 

The field of Agentic AI security continues to take shape. Standards like ISO 42001 and regulations such as the EU AI Act are in development, and industry best practices are actively maturing. That’s why collaboration is essential. SAP is contributing to the conversations held with industry groups focused on these challenges, including OWASP GenAI initiatives. We’re not just adopting ideas, we’re helping shape them, working with peers and regulators to advance the state of AI security. Our teams bring deep expertise in both enterprise security and AI systems, offering a perspective that’s helping guide how the broader ecosystem approaches agentic risks. 

Transparency remains central to how SAP approaches product security. As we continue evolving our work with AI, we’re committed to sharing what we learn through resources like the SAP Trust Center. Security is not a one-time effort. It is a continuous process, especially with systems as dynamic as Agentic AI. 

Threat modeling helps us stay ahead of these evolving risks and supports the design of systems that are both capable and safe. As Agentic AI becomes more embedded in enterprise workflows, this kind of proactive thinking becomes essential. 

SAP is proud to contribute to shaping the future of secure AI. By collaborating across the industry and applying deep expertise from our teams, we’re helping advance practical, forward-looking approaches to securing the next generation of intelligent systems.
